<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 325, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[852, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 587, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 728, 634]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 603, 88]]<|/det|>
A student determines the internal diameter \(d\) of a test-tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 104, 530, 120]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is assembled as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 141, 707, 360]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 384, 532, 401]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 262, 434]]<|/det|>
The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 448, 184, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 448, 685, 464]]<|/det|>
fills a measuring cylinder with water up to the \(100cm^{3}\) mark．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 466, 726, 482]]<|/det|>
pours some water from the measuring cylinder into the test-tube.

The internal diameter \(d\) of a cylinder is given by the equation \(d = k \sqrt{G}\), where \(k = 1.13 \text{ cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 740, 431, 756]]<|/det|>

<pre>2 A student investigates a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 918, 134]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 149, 136, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 653, 165]]<|/det|>

The student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 616, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 757, 918, 785]]<|/det|>

Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{XY}\).

<form>\(V_{XY} = ............................................................. V\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 371, 136, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 371, 640, 387]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 392, 537, 422]]<|/det|>
\[
I = \frac{V_{XY}}{R},
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 432, 302, 448]]<|/det|>
where \(R = 470 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 462, 662, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[557, 577, 920, 593]]<|/det|>

closes the switch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 660, 585, 676]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 677, 480, 693]]<|/det|>

\[
V_{YZ} = .................................................. 2.2V
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 755, 750, 772]]<|/det|>
<pre>Calculate the resistance \(R_B\) of the LDR in bright light using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[454, 776, 546, 807]]<|/det|>
\[
R_B = \frac{V_{YZ}}{I} .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[545, 905, 920, 921]]<|/det|>
<form>\(R_B = ..................................................... \Omega\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 73, 136, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 73, 184, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 918, 105]]<|/det|> The student covers the LDR with a piece of card and repeats the procedure described in (b) and (d). <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[545, 118, 885, 140]]<|/det|> \[ V_{XY} = \ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots 0.15V \] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[545, 155, 885, 177]]<|/det|> \[ V_{YZ} = \ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ 2.9V \] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 190, 771, 207]]<|/det|> Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{D}}\) of the LDR in the dark using the equation: <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 211, 576, 245]]<|/det|> \[ R_{\mathrm{D}} = \frac{470 \Omega \times V_{YZ}}{V_{XY}} . \] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 339, 885, 356]]<|/det|> \[ R_{\mathrm{D}} = \ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots \Omega \quad [1] \] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 370, 184, 386]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 370, 918, 418]]<|/det|> The student removes the card from the top of the LDR and slowly lifts it vertically upwards away from the LDR until the card is 30 cm above the LDR. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 666, 492]]<|/det|>
The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 497, 556, 525]]<|/det|>
\[
f=\frac{(D^{2}-d^{2})}{4 D} .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 917, 569]]<|/det|>
Use the value of \(D\) from (a) and \(d\) from (b)(ii) to calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 582, 492, 598]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 694, 885, 710]]<|/det|>
<form>\(f_{1} = ............................................................$ cm [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 73, 136, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure in (a) and (b) for an object to screen distance \(D=100.0 \mathrm{~cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 103, 540, 119]]<|/det|>
The student records the values of \(X, Y\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[553, 132, 815, 155]]<|/det|>
\[
X= ............................................. 18.1 \text { cm }
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[553, 170, 815, 192]]<|/det|>
\[
Y= ............................................. 81.8 \text { cm }
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[553, 207, 815, 228]]<|/det|>
\[
d= ............................................. 63.7 \text { cm }
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 242, 841, 258]]<|/det|>
<pre>Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens using the equation in (c).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[553, 353, 815, 369]]<|/det|>
<form>\(f_{2}= ............................................................. \text { cm }[1]\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 383, 136, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10 \%\) of each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 430, 813, 446]]<|/det|>
<pre>State whether your values of \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) from (c) and (d) can be considered equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 460, 504, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 136, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 920, 105]]<|/det|>
State one technique to use when doing this type of experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is focused as clearly as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 182, 876, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 212, 184, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 212, 629, 228]]<|/det|>
This experiment is usually done in a darkened room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 747, 258]]<|/det|>
Explain how this makes it easier to see when the image is in focus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[835, 335, 920, 351]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 773, 88]]<|/det|>
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down for 5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 103, 917, 135]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the rate of cooling of the hot water depends upon the initial temperature of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 150, 688, 166]]<|/det|>
The rate of cooling of the water can be calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[323, 171, 674, 202]]<|/det|>
\[
\text { rate of cooling }=\frac{\text { decrease in temperature }}{\text { time taken }} .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 212, 304, 228]]<|/det|>
You are provided with:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 243, 340, 258]]<|/det|>
· a supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 260, 280, 272]]<|/det|>
· an electric kettle

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 275, 350, 289]]<|/det|>
· a \(250cm^{3}\) glass beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 291, 335, 305]]<|/det|>
· a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 321, 565, 337]]<|/det|>
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 352, 293, 368]]<|/det|>
In your plan, include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 383, 392, 398]]<|/det|>
· any other apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 400, 917, 428]]<|/det|>
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 430, 392, 444]]<|/det|>
· the variables you will control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 446, 917, 475]]<|/det|>
· a results table to record your measurements (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 477, 615, 492]]<|/det|>
· how you will process your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 507, 418, 523]]<|/det|>
You may include a labelled diagram.
